contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks to Jehoiachin as if it were possible for him to be the ring on Yahweh's hand. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: even if you ... were the signet on my right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh states what would have happened if the priests and false prophets had participated in Yahweh's council meeting in heaven. This hypothetical situation is impossible. Alternate translation: "if they had truly listened to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: if they had stood in my council meeting

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh knows is not true. Alternate translation: "If they were prophets, and if the word of Yahweh had truly come to them, they would beg" or "Because they are not prophets and the word of Yahweh has not truly come to them, they will not beg" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: If they are prophets, and if the word of Yahweh has truly come to them, let them beg

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh never expects to truly happen. Alternate translation: "These permanent things will never vanish ... and Israel's descendants will never stop from forever being a nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: Only if these permanent things vanish ... will Israel's descendants ever stop from forever being a nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh never expects to truly happen. Alternate translation: "The highest heavens can never be measured, and the earth's foundation below can never be discovered, and I will never reject all of Israel's descendants" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: Only if the highest heavens can be measured, and only if the earth's foundation below can be discovered, will I reject all of Israel's descendants

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words begin a hypothetical statement that describe a situation that will never occur. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: If you can break ... proper times

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hypothetical statement that begins with the words "If you can break my covenant ... times," in verse 20 ends here. No one can change day and night, and no one can change God's covenant with David. Alternate translation: "You know that you cannot break my covenant ...times, so you know that you will never be able to break my covenant with David my servant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: then you will be able to break my covenant with David my servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the beginning of a hypothetical statement that describes a situation that Yahweh never expects to be true.(See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: If I have not established ... and if I have not fixed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hypothetical statement that begins with the words "If I have not established the covenant" in verse 25 ends here. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

The hypothetical statement that begins with the words "If I have not established the covenant" in verse 25 ends here. This is a situation that Yahweh never expects to be true. Alternate translation: "I have established the covenant ... so I will never reject ... and I will bring" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: then I will reject ... and not bring

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a hypothetical situation that Yahweh does not expect to happen. Alternate translation: "Babylon will not go up ... or fortify ... destroyers will surely come from me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: if Babylon went up ... or fortified ... destroyers would come from me
